title-group.article-title: An optimal preview driver model applied to a non-linear vehicle and an impaired driver

contrib-group.aff: Concave Research Center, Concordia University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Thanh Phuc Le, CONCAVE Research Center, Concordia University, 1515 St., Catherine St., West, Montreal, Quebec H3G 1M8, Canada. Email: p_leth@encs.concordia.ca

abstract.p: This paper proposes an improved driver model based on the one introduced by MacAdam in 1981 where optimal preview control is applied. The details of the optimal preview driver model are derived. The modified model incorporating the steering angle into the performance index is used to compute the steering input. The parameters associated with reaction time and preview time characterize the adaptation of the driver to the changes of the vehicle, the road and the environment. The modified model exhibits better performance and its parameters are well related to the performance of the driver. The driver model is then coupled with a non-linear vehicle. Initial tests are performed to identify the driver’s parameters. The coupling of the driver and the non-linear vehicle introduces enhanced path-following. An impaired driver model can be obtained by reducing the optimal parameters. When the safety criteria are chosen, the threshold for safe driving is identified.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lateral handling of a vehicle is one of the most important tasks of a driver, along with regulating the longitudinal speed. Understanding the mechanism of driver lateral handling improves not only vehicle design towards minimizing traffic accidents due to direction tracking, but also driving assistance, such as steer-by-wire and autonomous car control. Control theory may quantify driver behavior as a closed-loop system, where the driver model is required to follow a path by continuous control of the steering wheel.

McRuer et al.1–3 performed experiments on human operators with various controlled elements. They concluded that the open-loop transfer function of a system including a human operator and a controlled element has the same pattern despite the change in transfer functions of the human and the controlled element. They proposed a ‘crossover model’, which is also known as the compensation model, to indentify the driver’s parameters. For the driving task, compensation is not the only driver’s duty. The future path is essential information contributing to the decision on the steering angle so that the driver can manipulate the vehicle smoothly. MacAdam4,5 applied optimal preview control to a driver–vehicle system following a path. The optimal steering angle is derived by minimizing the performance index which accounts for the lateral deviation. Also considering the driving task as the optimal control, Cole et al.6,7 investigated linear quadratic control, where the future road path is incorporated into the vehicle state. The driver is assumed to observe the road path in finite lateral values ahead of the vehicle, equally spaced in the longitudinal direction.

The goal of modeling the vehicle driver is to obtain a steering angle corresponding to an arbitrary path. Furthermore, the model’s parameters must reflect a physical interpretation of the driver’s behavior, which represents a considerable challenge, given human complexity. This paper presents a driver model developed by modifying the model of MacAdam,4,5 and attempts to relate its parameters to real circumstances. The steering cost is added to the cost function to compute the control input. The model is further configured to various road inputs to find the dependence of the parameters on road configurations and their relationship.

The paper also proposes a method to couple a linear driver model with a non-linear vehicle model. Feedback gains represent driver’s abilities to predict the vehicle response. The gains are identified by applying initial condition tests that are similar to what a driver learns at an initial stage. A driver model with reduced parameters is introduced as an impaired driver model. It is widely accepted that an impaired driver needs a longer time to react to an incident, and may not observe the road at distance. Therefore a longer reaction time and a shorter preview time are used to model such conditions.

sec.title: The vehicle model
sec.p: A driver acquainted with a vehicle’s responses is assumed to be skilful enough to handle driving tasks. He perceives the vehicle dynamics while driving. The experience acquired while driving the vehicle helps him to choose appropriate action. In the control model, vehicle dynamics which are similar to those acquired by the driver are described by the equations of motion. The driver may not actually know the equations, but he perceives, with some approximation, the expected output (e.g. lateral displacement) for a known input (e.g. steering angle). A vehicle model that incorporates the non-linear components may adversely affect an attempt to apply linear control theory in coupling the driver and the vehicle. This vehicle model may be used as a tool to quantify the driver’s parameters indicated by the linear model. Thus, a linear vehicle model which provides sufficient states but which reduces the complexity of the problem is used.

A linear bicycle model is considered by assuming that the vehicle is rigid and experiences negligible roll, travelling on a good road, with equal coefficients of friction on the left and right sides and facing only small differences in longitudinal forces.8–10 Hence the left and right tires are lumped into an equivalent axle. The pair of tires on the axle is represented by a single tire with double the cornering stiffness. The lateral forces acting on the tires are also assumed to be equal on the left and right sides. The vehicle has longitudinal and lateral translation and yaw, as shown in Figure 1.

sec.title: The driver model
sec.p: The lateral control of a vehicle involves the driver observing the path and processing this information in the context of current motion to yield the appropriate steering input.11 For common driving circumstances the driver achieves sufficient future path information before initiating the maneuver. For instance, before making a double-lane-change, the geometry of the required path is anticipated and previewed. The path which is out of the preview distance may not account for generating the current steering control. Subsequently the vehicle performs individual tasks, such as double-lane-change, maintaining straight line, lane-change, and so on.

Figure 2 illustrates a single task as the curve defined by the coordinates of the path that the driver must follow. The strategy of driving is the single-point preview. The driver captures the road path by several key points in view of the moving-vehicle framework.11 The nearest point within the preview distance is processed for the steering input. In Figure 2, G represents that point. The driver may not observe every point forming the continuous curve but approximately generates the path based on the points F and G, where F is the beginning of the curve. Therefore, the path consisting of line segments (which is used in the simulations in Figures 6 and 7) is the input to the driver. Another consideration is that the lateral distances of the path seen by the driver are relative to the longitudinal axis, x, of the vehicle and not the absolute axis, X. For instance, they are yF, yG, and yH.

The current lateral position and head angle of the vehicle are y(t) and ψ(t), respectively. Let η = t+Tp be the anticipated future time, where Tp is the preview time derived from the preview distance depending on the driver’s capability. If the head angle at the time t is small and neglected, and the vehicle center coincides with the path center, the absolute lateral path will be f(η)=yp(η), the relative path observed by the driver. This investigation uses the absolute lateral path f(η) as the input to the driver, with the assumptions discussed above.

sec.p: To evaluate the appropriateness of the driver model in conjunction with that of the vehicle, the system performance is assessed while maintaining a straight line and performing lane-change and double-lane-change maneuvers.

sec.title: The driver–vehicle response
sec.p: Maintaining a straight line path represents the most frequent driving task. The driver often adjusts the steering wheel to eliminate lateral deviation due to road fluctuation and wind disturbance. The system is stable if it recovers its state after a disturbance. The stability of the system is assessed by the root locus of the closed-loop system. The open-loop transfer function of the system is illustrated in Figure 3 as

Two un-determined parameters are the preview time, T*, and the delay time, τ. Various experiments were performed to identify the values of these parameters.15,16 Depending on the method and experiment set-up, the results may differ considerably.

To incorporate the values into the model, initial tests were conducted. Each value of τ is accompanied by an optimal value of T*, where a minimum value of the cost function is obtained. When the driver model has a larger delay time, the preview time must be larger in order to minimize the cost function. The relation of the preview time, delay time and cost function is illustrated in Figure 4.

caption.p: The relation of the preview time, delay time and cost function.

sec.p: Five values of delay time, varying from 0.3 s to 0.7 s are implemented in the driver model. The optimal preview time, achieved at τ = 0.7 s, is 2.22 s that is larger than 1.46 s at τ = 0.3 s. The value of the cost function at τ = 0.7 s (C = 0.86) is also higher than that at τ = 0.3 s (C = 0.67). The smaller delay time introduces a lower value of the cost function resulting in better performance. However, the delay time of the driver model represents the ability of the driver to cope with information processing, decision and reaction. The driver needs a sufficient delay time to give a proper response. For the purpose of modeling the driver, the delay time is taken at 0.4 s or higher.16 Assuming that the driver functioning well, then, T* = 1.6 s and τ = 0.4 s have been chosen as moderate values.

The root locus of the closed-loop system with varying Tp and τ is shown in Figure 5, where the conjugated parts are removed. Tp denotes the preview time of the driver model, including the optimal preview time, T*. Figure 5(a) illustrates the roots of the system when the preview time changes from 1.2 s to 0.45 s for a constant delay time τ = 0.4 s. The arrow indicates the trend of the roots when the preview time is decreased. The dominant complex root passes through the imaginary axis and locates in the right plane when the preview time approaches 0.85 s.

caption.p: The root locus of the closed-loop system with (a) varying Tp and (b) varying τ.

sec.p: Figure 5(b) presents the roots of the driver–vehicle system when the delay time, τ, varies in the range 0.5–1.5 s while Tp = 1.6 s. When τ is increased, the dominant roots translate to the right, at τ = 0.8s. The system is unstable whenever there is a root in the right plane. These parameters physically relate to the human driver. The driver is capable of driving if he has a sufficiently large preview time and a short reaction time.

Figure 6 illustrates the time history of the dynamic response of the driver–vehicle system to a double-lane-change maneuver. The model performs tracking to the path defined by the previewed path depicted in Figure 6(a). The modified model is compared with the model of MacAdam.5 The peak value of the lateral acceleration, yaw rate and steering angle for the modified model slightly reduce. The peak lateral acceleration of the modified driver–vehicle model is 0.21 g, which means a reduction of 12%. The peak yaw rate of the modified driver–vehicle model is 0.086 rad/s, which is 11% lower than that of the MacAdam model. The peak steering angle is also reduced 12.5%; 0.12 rad for the modified model compared to 0.16 rad for the model of MacAdam. sec.p: The result is Jm = 0.628 for the modified model while that of the MacAdam model is JM = 0.663, which are the minimum values of the cost function at the preview time Tp = 1.65 s and reaction time τ = 0.4 s. By including the steering constraint in the cost function, the vehicle needs less effort while ensuring good path-following. The smaller effort of the modified driver–vehicle model is expressed as the smaller required steering control and thus, the lower lateral acceleration and yaw rate.

The modified model performs three lane-changes with different curvature as depicted in Figure 7(a). The lane-change 1 corresponds to the largest curvature where the lane-change angle is 20°. The lane-change angle for lane-changes 2 and 3 are 5.2° and 2.3°, respectively.

caption.p: Three levels of lane-change and their cost.

sec.p: The cost associated with each lane-change is shown in Figure 7(b), where the reaction time is fixed at 0.4 s and the preview time varies from 1.1 s to 2.1 s. With the restricted lane-change (denoted by lane-change 1), the system barely follows the path, resulting the large cost function value of C1 = 0.678. Compared to the easy lane-change (denoted by lane-change 3), the cost C3 = 0.033 proves that the system needs little effort to pass the task while achieving the least lateral deviation. Figure 7(b) also shows that the system meets the optimal performance at different Tp, corresponding to different lane-changes, Tp1 = 1.61 s, Tp2 = 1.59 s and Tp3 = 1.54 s for lane-changes 1, 2 and 3, respectively. Relating to the driving reality, the larger the curvature of the road, the larger the preview time the driver has. The driver needs to obtain more future path information to deal with such challenges.

The driver–vehicle responses show that incorporating the steering input into the cost function introduces better performance to the driver–vehicle system. The values of the parameters found via the simulations reflect the behavior of the driver. The good driver is capable of reacting quickly to the unexpected disturbance and observing far ahead of the vehicle. The driver is suitable for driving if he has a sufficiently small delay in reaction and a large preview time. The driver model also frequently adapts its parameters to the road.

sec.title: The coupling of the driver model and the non-linear vehicle, and the representation of deteriorated driving skills
sec.p: Investigating the driver–vehicle system, as in Figure 3, reveals that the system comprises the delay function, e-τs, the vehicle transfer function, G(s), and the gains. The delay function and gains characterize the driver’s performance by the factors that are the effective delay time, τ, in e-τs and the optimal preview time, T*, in K1, K2 and CeAT*. The gain K1 and K2 only depend on T* and are computed as in equations (10) and (11). The terms K1 and CeAT*are mentioned in equation (7) as the preview gains. K1 represents the preview gain in steering input with zero state. The matrix (1×4) of gains CeAT*expresses the driver’s preview in the current vehicle state with zero steering input. It means that the lateral position of vehicle after a duration T* is the summation of previewed components: steering input, δsw(t), lateral velocity, v(t), yaw rate, r(t), lateral position, y(t) and yaw angle, ψ(t).

There is only the transfer function G(s) in Figure 3 which represents the vehicle state that leads to the attempt to model the system of driver and non-linear vehicle. It is expected that the driver uses the same scheme as the one in Figure 3 to manipulate the non-linear vehicle, as illustrated in Figure 8.

caption.p: The system of driver and non-linear vehicle.

sec.p: Hence, the linear vehicle is replaced by the non-linear one where its equations of motion are as derived in Appendix 2. This non-linear vehicle model was investigated by earlier researchers,17–19 including the longitudinal and lateral motion, yaw, roll and the rotation of the four wheels. The chosen outputs are lateral velocity, v(t), yaw rate, r(t), lateral position, y(t) and yaw angle, ψ(t). The issue is the identification of gains, K1, K2 and M, corresponding to the non-linear vehicle. As discussed above, K1 and M are preview gains for steering input and vehicle state, respectively. K2 is computed from K1 by applying equation (10). For the non-linear vehicle, K1 is the ratio of lateral position output to steering input while states are set to zero. Mv of M = [MvMrMyMψ] is the ratio of lateral position output to current lateral velocity while steering input and other states are zero. Mr, My and Mψ are identified by a similar method. The gains of the non-linear and linear vehicles are illustrated in Figure 9. These values are calculated at Tp = 1.6 s and τ = 0.4 s.

caption.p: Preview gains of the linear vehicle and the non-linear vehicle.

sec.p: The preview gains of a vehicle are unique and different from those of other vehicles. For instance, the yaw gain, Mr, of the linear vehicle is 5.12 m·s, while that of the non-linear vehicle is 5.8 m·s. The preview gains for outputs of the non-linear vehicle are also significantly different. For instance, the lateral velocity gain, Mv, of the non-linear vehicle is 0.7 s, while the head angle gain, Mψ, is 30 m. These preview gains are dependent on the characteristics of the vehicle, such as the center of gravity, wheel base and tires. The driver is considered to be capable of predicting the future states of the vehicle based on the feedback of lateral velocity, yaw velocity, lateral position and head angle. The feedback gains are assumed to be equal to the preview gains calculated above.

Figure 10 illustrates the sensitivity of the lateral performance to the variations in lateral position gain, My, head angle gain, Mψ, roll stiffness, kp and height of CG, h. For the driver model’s parameters, the results show that variations in both My and Mψ primarily affect the lateral performance. Since the signs of the value SJy,My indicate an increase (+) or decrease (–) in lateral response, Figure 10(a) shows that variations in My yield an increase or decrease in lateral performance for My > 1 and My < 1, respectively. This means that when My < 1, an increase in My yields a decrease in Jy, and when My > 1, an increase in My yields an increase in Jy. My = 1 is considered the optimal lateral position gain. The lateral performance will become worse if the gain is smaller or greater than 1. The effect of Mψ on Jy is in a similar manner, as in Figure 10(b). Mψ = 31 is considered the optimal head angle gain. A comparison of response sensitivity to variations in My and Mψ reveals that the lateral response of the vehicle is relatively more sensitive to variations in My.

caption.p: Sensitivity of lateral performance to variations in My, Mψ, h and kp.

sec.p: For the vehicle’s parameters, the results show that variations in h and kp also affect the lateral performance, as in Figure10(c) and (d). An increase in h results in an increase in Jy, while an increase in kp yields a decrease in Jy. It means that a larger CG height results in a worse lateral performance, while a larger roll-stiffness results in a better lateral performance. The further investigation of Figure 10 reveals a method to reduce the lateral position error. If the driver model’s parameters are not at the optimal values (My ≠ 1 and Mψ ≠ 31) the lateral performance may be improved by decreasing the CG height and increasing the roll-stiffness.

The lane-change test with the coupled driver and non-linear vehicle model is shown in Figure 11. The parameters of the driver model for a specific vehicle model are identified by applying the initial tests, and they comprise the gains used to predict the future state of the vehicle in order to minimize the lateral error. The lateral displacement is computed while applying three values of preview time. A shorter preview time introduces a larger over-shoot.

caption.p: Lateral position of the non-linear vehicle with three values of preview time.

sec.p: The advantage of the non-linear vehicle model is to achieve more details of the vehicle’s response, such as the roll angle, roll rate, load transfer and force distributed on the wheels. The roll angle of the non-linear vehicle, as shown in Figure 12, is not available for the linear vehicle. The roll angle was measured when the driver and non-linear vehicle performed a lane-change, as in Figure 11. Three values of the preview time are implemented—Tp = 1.5 s, 1.6 s and 1.7 s—while the constant delay time is τ = 0.4 s. The vehicle roll depends not only on the path required but also on the driver’s performance, identified by the parameters. For this case, the driver–vehicle system with the preview time Tp = 1.7 s introduces lower roll compared to the system with Tp = 1.5 s. The driver model with the longer preview time increased the stability of the vehicle against a roll-over situation. Therefore, the non-linear vehicle coupled to the driver model provides specific information aiding vehicle design.

caption.p: Roll angle of the non-linear vehicle with three values of preview time.

sec.p: The following discussion is on an arbitrary-selected non-linear vehicle model which is described by the system of equations of motion. The method presented above provides a driver-to-vehicle model. The unknown gains are easy to evaluate by applying few initial tests. The tests determine the future lateral position of the vehicle with separate initial conditions. The steering angle gain, K1, is obtained by applying as a step steering angle while states are zero. The lateral velocity gain, Mv, is obtained by applying an initial lateral velocity while steering angle and other states are zero. The other gains—Mr, My, and Mψ—may be identified by the same scheme. The resulting coefficients are considered as the driver’s preview gains, with the assumption that the driver may perceive the future states of the vehicle.

The preview gain, which is the ratio of the lateral position to the initial state, depends on the preview time. Therefore, the preview time defines the performance of the model of the driver and the non-linear vehicle. Corresponding to a delay time, there is a preview time where the performance index is obtained at a minimum value. The optimal preview time is identified by incorporating varying preview times into the model. The optimal preview time is achieved at the point that the performance index increases when the preview time either increases or decreases. For instance, the above non-linear vehicle achieves the best performance at the preview time Tp = 1.55 s, while the delay time τ = 0.4 s. The optimal path-following is illustrated in Figure 13 as the bold curve. The lateral position of the vehicle is represented by the position of its CG.

caption.p: The performance of the non-linear vehicle model with levels of deterioration.

sec.p: The parameters of the driver model are obtained under the assumption that the driver is trained and is in good condition for driving. The driver’s performance, however, depends on other factors, such as the environment, mood, condition of the vehicle and the influence of alcohol and drugs. The vehicle performance may be adversely affected if the driver’s skills deteriorate. Levels of deterioration of 25%, 50% and 70% are represented in Figure 13. Deterioration of 50% means the preview time is 50% shorter, and the delay time is 50% longer, than optimal. Hence, the deteriorated preview time and delay time are Tp = 0.78 s and τ = 0.6 s. The preview gains also change due to change of the preview time. If the lane variation exceeding Δy = 0.5 m is used as the critical lateral deviation, then maneuvers with 50% and 70% deterioration may not satisfy this requirement. For this case, the maximum allowed reduction of driving skills is 46%, corresponding to Tp = 0.84 s and τ = 0.58 s. It is considered that the vehicle remains within the lane as long as the deviation of the CG does not exceed 0.5 m. A deviation larger than 0.5 m is associated with an interference by the vehicle with the adjacent lane, thus creating a significantly higher risk of a collision.

The driver model with deteriorated parameters exhibits higher lateral deviation and oscillation. After performing a curved path, the vehicle is unable to return to the straight path without an oscillation. As seen in Figure 13, the optimal driver model takes about 50 m to return to the straight line, while the 25% deterioration model takes about 100 m. A longer distance still is required for the model with 50% and 70% deterioration. This characteristic relates to the performance of an alcohol-affected driver, where the weaving car is a characteristic of this type of impairment. The driver may not maintain the lane due to the road excitation or wind disturbance. By changing the parameters, the driver model may represent such a driver.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The proposed model provides another useful tool for quantifying human performance in driving a specific vehicle. The model consists of the coupling of a linear vehicle model and an optimal preview driver model through the predicted lateral error and steering angle that give good performance with various path inputs. The parameters express the physical impact of the driver’s behavior. The driver model is out of control of the vehicle for a preview time smaller than 0.85 s and the reaction time larger than 0.8 s. The driver model also adapts its parameters to the changing path curvature.

The modified driver model has potential application to a non-linear vehicle, where the preview gains are determined by initial tests. The feedback gains of lateral velocity, yaw velocity, lateral position and head angle vary significantly. The driver–non-linear vehicle system performs a lane-change maneuver successfully, as does the linear system. The non-linear vehicle provides various outputs that depend on driver parameters. For an arbitrary non-linear vehicle, the proposed model may be applied as a virtual driver for vehicle design.

The parameters of the driver model may change to represent a driver with deteriorated skills. The performance of the driver model exhibits a larger lateral deviation. The level of impairment when the driver model is considered still suitable for driving a vehicle model is obtained by applying the safe driving criteria. The impaired driver model may contribute to road safety research. Further application of the impaired driver model should be on adapting the vehicle to the driver. The response of a vehicle with an impaired driver can be improved by changing the vehicle parameters. A tire pressure control system is capable of adjusting the air pressure in the pneumatic tires in order to change the cornering stiffness of the tire. Active suspension control may regulate the hydraulic pressure in dampers to change not only the damping ratio but also the suspension stiffness and the height of center of gravity. The parameters are adjusted to reduce the impact of amplification of driver impairment by the vehicle and improve driver–vehicle safety.
